user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__shared:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__shared (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.single)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-I' or '--single'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.unique)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-U' or '--unique'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.shared = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The ternary expression returns one of two enum values depending on the runtime value of param_name[1], so both branches are potentially reachable. (Note: reading param_name[1] when param_name has length < 2 is undefined behaviour but not an instance of unreachable code.)
